messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 65 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Behavior Trees in Robot Control Systems

Paper Abstract: Abstract In this paper we will give a control theoretic perspective on the research area of behavior trees in robotics. The key idea underlying behavior trees is to make use of modularity, hierarchies and feedback, in order to handle the complexity of a versatile robot control system. Modularity is a well-known tool to handle software complexity by enabling development, debugging and extension of separate modules without having detailed knowledge of the entire system. A hierarchy of such modules is natural, since robot tasks can often be decomposed into a hierarchy of sub-tasks. Finally, feedback control is a fundamental tool for handling uncertainties and disturbances in any low level control system, but in order to enable feedback control on the higher level, where one module decides what submodule to execute, information regarding progress and applicability of each submodule needs to be shared in the module interfaces. We will describe how these three concepts come to use in theoretical analysis, practical design, as well as extensions and combinations with other ideas from control theory and robotics.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 65 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 65"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Hierarchical modularity",
        "A Structure for Plans and Behavior",
        "UMCP: a sound and complete procedure for hierarchical task-network planning",
        "A behavior language for story-based believable agents",
        "Handling Complexity in the Halo 2 AI",
        "Query-Enabled Behavior Trees",
        "Increasing Modularity of UAV Control Systems using Computer Game Behavior Trees",
        "An Integrated System for Autonomous Robotics Manipulation",
        "Statecharts: a visual formalism for complex systems",
        "An Expressiveness Hierarchy of Behavior Trees and Related Architectures",
        "A Survey of Behavior Trees in Robotics and AI",
        "Behavior Trees in Robotics and AI : An Introduction",
        "How Behavior Trees Modularize Hybrid Control Systems and Generalize Sequential Behavior Compositions, the Subsumption Architecture, and Decision Trees",
        "Convergence Analysis of Hybrid Control Systems in the Form of Backward Chained Behavior Trees",
        "Continuous-time behavior trees as discontinuous dynamical systems",
        "On the Implementation of Behavior Trees in Robotics",
        "Discontinuous dynamical systems",
        "Differential Equations with Discontinuous Righthand Sides: Control Systems",
        "On modularity in reactive control architectures, with an application to formal verification",
        "Transitiv orientierbare Graphen",
        "Structured Testing: A Testing Methodology Using the Cyclomatic Complexity Metric",
        "Sequential Composition of Dynamically Dexterous Robot Behaviors",
        "Integrated Planning and Control for Convex-bodied Nonholonomic Systems using Local Feedback Control Policies",
        "Simulation-based LQR-trees with input and state constraints",
        "Representing Robot Task Plans as Robust Logical-Dynamical Systems",
        "Control Barrier Functions: Theory and Applications",
        "Autonomous UCAV Strike Missions Using Behavior Control Lyapunov Functions",
        "Combining Control Barrier Functions and Behavior Trees for Multi-Agent Underwater Coverage Missions",
        "Autonomous Horizons: System Autonomy in the Air Force â€“ A Path to the Future. Volume I: Human-AutonomyTeaming",
        "User Experience of the CoSTAR System for Instruction of Collaborative Robots",
        "Grandmaster level in StarCraft II using multi-agent reinforcement learning",
        "A Framework for Constrained and Adaptive Behavior-Based Agents",
        "Integrating Reinforcement Learning into Behavior Trees by Hierarchical Composition",
        "Adding Neural Network Controllers to Behavior Trees without Destroying Performance Guarantees",
        "QL-BT: Enhancing Behaviour Tree Design and Implementation with Q-Learning",
        "A Reinforcement Learning Behavior Tree Framework for Game AI",
        "Combining Behavior Trees with MAXQ Learning to Facilitate CGFs Behavior Modeling",
        "Behavior tree design of intelligent behavior of non-player character (NPC) based on Unity3D",
        "Simulation Results on Selector Adaptation in Behavior Trees",
        "A genetic algorithm tutorial",
        "On the locality of grammatical evolution",
        "A Comparison of Bloat Control Methods for Genetic Programming",
        "Learning of Behavior Trees for Autonomous Agents",
        "Evolving Instinctive Behaviour in Resource-Constrained Autonomous Agents Using Grammatical Evolution",
        "Evolving Behaviour Trees for the Commercial Game DEFCON",
        "Evolutionary Behavior Tree Approaches for Navigating Platform Games",
        "Learning Behavior Trees with Genetic Programming in Unpredictable Environments",
        "Automatic Difficulty Management and Testing in Games Using a Framework Based on Behavior Trees and Genetic Algorithms",
        "Combining Planning and Learning of Behavior Trees for Robotic Assembly",
        "Learning Swarm Behaviors Using Grammatical Evolution and Behavior Trees",
        "Evolving Behaviour Trees for Swarm Robotics",
        "Optimized Execution of PDDL Plans using Behavior Trees",
        "Towards Blended Reactive Planning and Acting using Behavior Trees",
        "Automatic Safe Behaviour Tree Synthesis for Autonomous Agents",
        "On-the-Fly Decentralized Tasking of Autonomous Vehicles",
        "An Autonomous Task Algorithm Based on Behavior Trees for Robot",
        "Capturing the Essence: Towards the Automated Generation of Transparent Behavior Models",
        "Behavior Trees as a Control Architecture in the Automatic Modular Design of Robot Swarms",
        "A Hybrid Approach to Planning and Execution in Dynamic Environments Through Hierarchical Task Networks and Behavior Trees",
        "Extended Behavior Trees for Quick Definition of Flexible Robotic Tasks",
        "Integration of an Automated Hierarchical Task Planner in ROS Using Behaviour Trees",
        "Reasoning and Learning for Awareness and Adaptation",
        "Synthesis of Correct-by-Construction Behavior Trees",
        "Autonomous Task Planning and Acting for Micro Aerial Vehicles",
        "A Framework for Formal Verification of Behavior Trees with Linear Temporal Logic"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 65 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Behavior Trees in Robot Control Systems, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
